thread.title: Rhinos stymie Louisville, reach USL final with 1-0 win
thread.title_full: Rhinos stymie Louisville, reach USL final with 1-0 win

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Rhinos stymie Louisville, reach USL final with 1-0 win
text:
The way the Rhinos attacked Louisville City FC in waves over the first 45 minutes, Saturday night’s USL Eastern Conference Finals appeared to be a mismatch with the league’s top defense turning the tables on its highest-scoring team. But then again, it’s never easy getting to a championship match.
Second-seeded Louisville tried to counter-punch in the second half and found some success as yellow cards started to mount for Rochester, but the visitors couldn’t find a goal and just as they’ve done all season, the Rhinos found a way to win. The top seeds made a 21st-minute goal by Vassilis Apostolopoulos hold up for a 1-0 victory in front of a throaty crowd of 5,561 fans at Sahlen’s Stadium.
They did it by playing a man short over the final 12 minutes after a red-card ejection to top scorer Steevan Dos Santos. Standing only a few yards from an official at midfield, the forward exchanged words with Aodhan Quinn then head-butted the Louisville midfielder. As a result, Dos Santos (10 goals) will miss Friday’s 7:30 p.m. USL Championship.
Rochester (19-1-10) plays the Western Conference winner – No. 2 OKC Energy or No. 5 L.A. Galaxy II, who play Sunday – in the title match. After winning four crowns in their first six years, the Rhinos are in search of their first since 2001.
“I’m really proud of this group. We brought the same mentality we brought all year. We didn’t give them anything,” said Rhinos team captain and midfielder, Tony Walls. “The top goal-scoring team in the league, whatever you want to read, whatever you want to write, I didn’t see it.”
Louisville (15-9-6), an expansion team, led the USL with 55 goals and boasted the league’s top scorer in Matt Fondy. He had 24 goals coming into Saturday. He’ll leave Rochester with the same number after the Rhinos’ hustling, tough defense held him to no shots and Louisville to only three.
Buy Photo Rochester Rhinos' Steevan Humberto Fortes dos Santos and Louisville City's Bryan Burke jump for the ball in the second half at Sahlen's Stadium in Rochester. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Almost remarkably, Rochester has shut out 19 of the 30 opponents, allowed only 15 goals and outscored teams 26-6 at home while going 14-0-2.
“We know it would take a whole team to shut down a player on a tear like (Fondy was) on, the season that he’s had,” said Grant Van deCasteele, one of the Rhinos’ big central defenders.
Apostolopoulos is the other and the 27-year-old from Greece picked a heck of a time to score his first goal. The play started with a corner kick from Kenardo Forbes, who gave Louisville fits all night. Dos Santos snapped a 12-yard header at the feet of goalie Scott Goodwin, who bobbled it. Walls tried to get a foot on it, but the ball bounced out and Apostolopoulos one-timed it back in.
“That’s just being hungry in the box, being first to the ball,” Walls said. “Vassilis of all people, I’m glad he got the goal.”
Added Apostolopoulos, whose defense is sharper than his English: “We like the big games.”
Friday will be the ninth final in the Rhinos’ 20-year history and first since 2006. If you’re looking for irony, try this: That’s when Bob Lilley’s Vancouver Whitecaps beat the Rhinos 3-0 in Rochester. Lilley, of course, is in his fourth season coaching the Rhinos.
“Every time we found (Alex) Dixon, Kenardo or Steevan in transition, there was a lot of space,” Lilley said of the first half, when he liked that Louisville was only using three defenders.
The visitors changed tactics in the second half, played over the top more. They still barely got a sniff at Rhinos goalie Brandon Miller (16 shutouts), whose defense may have to pitch another shutout next week when the Rhinos are shorthanded.
“It’s a big loss,” Lilley said of Dos Santos. “The guy’s human. He was fouled all night. The ref chose to give us yellows every time and I thought he was lenient with their players. … Listen, it was a mistake on his part and it’s a mistake we’re going to have to overcome, but we’re a team and it’s up to other guys stepping up.”
JDIVERON@Gannett.com
No. 1 Rhinos 1, No. Louisville City FC 0
Scoring: 1, Rhinos, Vassilis Apostolopoulos (unassisted) 21st minute.
Shots: Louisville 3, Rhinos 8. Corner kicks: Louisville 1, Rhinos 4. Saves: Louisville 3, Rhinos 2. Yellow cards: Louisville 1 (Quinn 49), Rhinos 4 (McMahon 29, Forbes 49, Walls 60, Dixon 74). Red card: Rhinos 1 (Dos Santos 83).
Louisville City FC lineup: Scott Goodwin; Bryan Burke (Nate Polak, 79), Aohdan Quinn, Conor Shanosky (Adam West, 46), Tarek Morad; Kadeem Dacres, Juan Guzman (Ilija Ilic, 89), Magnus Rasmussen (Niall McCabe, 46), Sean Reynolds, Guy Abend (Charlie Adams, 46), Matt Fondy.
Rhinos lineup: Brandon Miller; Pat McMahon (Colin Rolfe, 72; Asani Samuels, 86), Grant Van deCasteele, Vassilis Apostolopoulos, Onua Obasi; Tony Walls, Mike Garzi (Sean Totsch, 55), Jonny Mendoza (Marcos Ugarte, 62), Kenardo Forbes (Nate Bordeau, 90), Alex Dixon; Steevan Dos Santos.
Attendance : 5,561.
